pages.text: Koolasuchus cleelandi comes from the Early Cretaceous, with fossils being found in the Wonthaggi Formation, Australia. It is a large temnospondyl, growing up to 3 m in length, and weighing up to 500 kg in weight. They are the youngest known temnospondyl.

The generic name derives from the surname of Lesley Kool, a well known Australian palaeontologist who has studied the region in which Koolasuchus comes from; and the Latin word 'suchus', to mean 'crocodile'. The specific name derives from the surname of Mike Cleeland, a Australian Geologist who found the first pieces of jaw material.
